1818.event: The World as Will and Representation (Schopenhauer)

1494.event: Treaty of Tordesillas sets colonial boundaries

1555.event: Peace of Augsburg legalizes German Lutheranism

1598.event: Edict of Nantes legalizes French Lutheranism

1620.event: Francis Bacon describes the scientific method

1648.event: Peace of Westphalia ends Thirty Years' War

1783.event: Treaty of Paris ends American Revolution

1815.event: Napoleon defeated by coalition at Waterloo

1920.event: Treaty of Versailles ends World War I

1947.event: Paris Peace Treaties conclude World War II

1240.event: Kievan Rus' falls to the Golden Horde

1429.event: Joan of Arc breaks the seige of Orleans

1791.event: A Vindication of the Rights of Woman (Wollstonecraft)

1953.event: Watson and Crick describe shape of DNA

800.event: Charlemagne crowned Emperor of the Romans

1687.event: Newton describes gravity and laws of motion

1942.event: Manhattan project develops the atom bomb

Philip II.name: Philip II
events: King of England and Ireland through marriage to Mary Tudor
Ruled during the Spanish Golden Age, the height of Spanish power
Sent the Spanish Armada to England to place a Catholic on the throne
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Maximilian II, Brother-in-law, img/hre/maximilian_ii.jpg

Philip III.name: Philip III
events: Expelled 300,000 Moriscos, Christiantized descendants of the Moors
Famine, poor taxation, and debt led to the economic decline of Spain
Intervened against German Protestants at the start of Thirty Years' War
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Ferdinand II, Brother-in-law, img/hre/ferdinand_ii.jpg

Philip IV.name: Philip IV
events: Acknowledged independence of the Dutch Republic
Lost Flanders and Northern Catalonia to the French
Portugal removes itself from union, crowning John IV

Charles II.name: Charles II
events: Sterile, lame, epileptic, senile, and always on the verge of death
Named the French Philip of Anjou as his successor
Succession crisis leads to war between Bourbons and Habsburgs

Philip V.name: Philip V
events: Grandson of French king, who hoped to secure throne for himsef
War ended with a treaty forbidding France and Spain from unifying
Failed to reclaim lost territories of Sicily and Sardinia

Louis I.name: Louis I
events: Father Philip abdicated, possibly to press claim for French throne
Died after only seven months as king

Philip V.name: Philip V
events: Came back to throne because younger son, Ferdinand, was not of age

Ferdinand VI.name: Ferdinand VI
events: Reformed taxation, which had heavily taxed Castile
Fought with Portugal over the colony of Sacramento in Uruguay
Died without issue, giving crown to younger brother Charles III

Charles III.name: Charles III
events: Won throne of Sicily and Naples through war of Polish succession
Succeeded to Spanish throne after death of older brother
Lost colonies to Britain, reclaiming them after American Revolution
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Leopold II, Son-in-law, img/hre/leopold_ii.jpg

Charles IV.name: Charles IV
events: Switched sides between France and Britain during Napoleonic Wars
Grew deeply unpopular and son Ferdinand attempted a failed coup
Popular revolt forced Charles to abdicate in favor of Ferdinand

Ferdinand VII.name: Ferdinand VII
events: Ascended throne during popular revolt against father Charles IV
Turned to Napoleon for support, who then imprisoned him in France

Joseph Bonaparte.name: Joseph Bonaparte
events: Ascended throne after being King of Naples and Sicily
Unpopularly seen as secular, a foreigner, and a Freemason
Returned to France after the defeat of Napoleon's forces

Ferdinand VII.name: Ferdinand VII
events: Re-installed by Bonaparte through the Treaty of Valençay
Napoleonic-era Congress of 1812 pressed for constitutional monarchy
Captured by partisans but freed by French Bourbon intervention

Isabella II.name: Isabella II
events: Contested by Carlists who refused to recognize a female heir
Replaced during Glorious Revolution with son of Italian king
Would-be Prussian heir caused France to declare war on Prussia
relationships: Two Sicilies, Francis I, Grandfather, img/italy/francis_i.jpg
Spain, Francisco de Paula, Uncle and father-in-law, img/spain/francisco_de_paula.jpg

Amadeo I.name: Amadeo I
events: Installed by military council, then contested by the Carlists
With no popular support, abdicated after assassination attempt
After abdication, Spain was proclaimed the First Spanish Republic
relationships: Italy, Victor Emmanuel II, Father, img/italy/victor_emmanuel_ii.jpg

Alfonso XII.name: Alfonso XII
events: Returned from exile following a military coup against the Republic
Defeated the Carlist pretender Charles V, ending the Carlist revolts
relationships: Two Sicilies, Don Carlos, Son-in-law, img/italy/carlos_two_sicilies.jpg

Alfonso XIII.name: Alfonso XIII
events: Born posthumously to Alfonso XII; regency held by mother
Lost rule over Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Philippines
Abdicated after municipal elections signaled the end of monarchy

Francisco Franco.name: Francisco Franco
events: Decorated military general in the years before the Second Republic
Led the far-right forces to victory in the Spanish Civil War
A repressive fascist, styled himself Caudillo & re-established monarchy
Following economic boom, Spanish Miracle, began to support liberalization
Without heir, named conservative grandson of Alfonso XIII his successor

Juan Carlos I.name: Juan Carlos I
events: Dismantled Francoist regime, creating democracy and constitution
Reconfirmed support for democracy after foiling Francoist coup
Following a series of family scandals, abdicated in favor of his son

Pepin the Short.name: Pepin the Short
events: Pushed out powerless Merovingian king with blessing of Pope
Donated Lombardi land to the pope, establishing Papal States
Annointed Patrician of the Romans by Pope Stephen II

Carloman I.name: Carloman I
events: Received the eastern part of Pepin's lands
Competed against Charlemagne for complete control of territory
After death, Charlemagne annexed his territory as sole ruler

Charlemagne.name: Charlemagne
events: Conquered and Christianized the Saxons and Frisians
Invaded Italy on appeal from Pope, assuming Lombard crown
Crowned Emperor of the Romans for securing Christian borders

Louis the Pious.name: Louis the Pious
events: As king of Aquitaine, served as co-emperor with his father
Attempted to keep empire together and repeal debauchery
Upon his death, civil war broke out and empire split three ways

Charles the Bald.name: Charles the Bald
events: Received western part of father's empire inTreaty of Verdun
Lost Brittany but won the Aquitaine and western Lorraine
Crowned Emperor of the Romans after death of nephew Louis II

Louis II.name: Louis II
events: Declined the crown of Emperor of the Romans
Agreed to truce with ruler of East Francia, Louis the Younger
After death, land divided between sons Carloman II and Louis III

Louis III.name: Louis III
events: Received Neustria and Francia from father Louis II
With brother Carloman II, repelled Scandinavian invaders
Ceded western Lotharingia to Louis the Younger of East Francia

Carloman II.name: Carloman II
events: Received Burgundy & Aquitaine from father Louis II
Tried unsuccessfully to defeat usurper of Provence, Boso

Charles the Fat.name: Charles the Fat
events: Received East Francia after death of brother, Louis the Younger
Received West Francia after deaths of Louis and Carloman
Seen as incompetent, deposed in East Francia by Arnulf

Odo.name: Odo
events: As Count of Paris, successfully defended against viking raiders
Elected King of the Franks after deposition of Charles the Fat
First king who was not of Merovingian or Carolingian blood

Charles III.name: Charles III
events: Ceded Normandy to Vikings in return for conversion and fealty
Received Lotharingia after death of Louis the Child
Killed usurper Robert but taken prisoner by Robert's son-in-law

Robert I.name: Robert I
events: Younger brother to Odo, defeated Northmen at Chartres
Elected king with support of dissident nobles and East Francia
Victorious at Battle of Soissons but killed in the battle

Rudolph.name: Rudolph
events: Son-in-law of Robert I, who was killed overthrowing Charles III
Made peace with Normans, granting them the Channel Islands
Lost Lorraine to Henry I and Laon to Herbert, captor of Charles

Louis IV.name: Louis IV
events: Spent his reign stuggling against vassal, Hugh the Great
Defended against invasion by Hugh who had support of Otto I
Captured and imprisoned by Hugh, who was excommunicated
relationships: England, Edward the Elder, Grandfather, img/england/edward_the_elder.jpg

Lothair III.name: Lothair III
events: Broke German alliance and spent reign fighting over Lorraine
Attempted to capture Otto II's family, prompting German Invasion
Defended with help of Hugh Capet, grandson of Hugh the Great
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Otto I, Uncle, img/hre/otto_i.jpg

Louis V.name: Louis V
events: Married widow of Aquitaine but lost it and failed to retake it
Unpopular uncle, Charles, passed over in favor of Hugh Capet
Last Carolingian King of Francia

Hugh Capet.name: Hugh Capet
events: First of a direct line of 15 Capetian kings of France
Son of Hugh the Great and grandson of Robert I
Faced internal struggles, but son acceeded without difficulty
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Otto I, Uncle, img/hre/otto_i.jpg

Robert II.name: Robert II
events: Brought Burgundy back under Frankish control for brief period
Pressed claim to fiefs as they became vacant, consolidating hold

Henry I.name: Henry I
events: Favored then fought William the Conquerer, Duke of Normandy
Signed decree of friendship with Henry III, Holy Roman Emperor
Civil war fought with younger brother, who was given Burgundy
relationships: England, William the Conquerer, Nephew, img/england/william_the_conquerer.png
Russia, Yaroslav the Wise, Father-in-law, img/russia/yaroslav.jpg

Philip I.name: Philip I
events: Supported Robert Curthose, Duke of Normandy, against England
Drawn into conflict with papacy for selling ecclesiastical positions
Added the Vexin and Bourges to Frankish rule

Louis VI.name: Louis VI
events: Contested the Vexin against Henry I of England
Repelled German invasion, who marched under French banner
Added Aquitaine to Francia by marrying Eleanor to his son

Louis VII.name: Louis VII
events: Marriage to Eleanor annulled, losing Aquitaine to England
Fought Henry II, Duke of Normandy and later King of England
Supported English Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury

Philip II.name: Philip II
events: Participated in Third Crusade with Richard I of England
Reclaimed French land from Angevin Empire of John I
Left France rich, paving the way for greatness in 13th century

Louis VIII.name: Louis VIII
events: Offered English throne by rebellious English barons
Recaptured fortress of Avignon from Albigensian heretics
Developed concept of fealty sworn to throne, not the individual

Louis IX.name: Louis IX
events: Prevented English Henry III from reclaiming Angevin land
Created provosts, bailiffs, and presumption of innocence
Captured and ransomed during Seventh Crusade

Philip III.name: Philip III
events: Annexed Toulouse to the French crown
Married son to heiress of Navarre, Champagne, and Brie
Fought the Aragonese, who opposed Angevin rule of Sicily

Philip IV.name: Philip IV
events: Fought England over Gascony and later Flanders for treachery
Clement V, a Gascon, moved papacy from Rome to Avignon
Attempted to have brother and son elected Holy Roman Emperor

Louis X.name: Louis X
events: Married daughter of Burgundy, who he imprisoned for adultery
Allowed serfs to buy freedom, beginning the end of serfdom
Attempted to raise money through charters to fund Flemish war

John I.name: John I
events: Born posthumously to Louis X
Died 5 days after birth, with throne going to uncle Philip V

Philip V.name: Philip V
events: Succession of Philip, over neice, set precedent for Salic law
Created independent Court of Finances and single currency
Created standardization of weights and measures

Charles IV.name: Charles IV
events: Invaded the Aquitaine, held by his vassal Edward II of England
Failed in bid for German throne and acquisition of Flanders
Died without heir, ending Capetian line, succeeded by cousin
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Henry VII, Father-in-law, img/hre/henry_vii.jpg

Philip VI.name: Philip VI
events: Gave Artois to his kin, fomenting discontent among his nobles
Resentment carried to Edward III, who had a claim to throne
Purchased Dauphiné but left France divided by war and plague

John II.name: John II
events: Inherited English war, breaking a truce and then losing terribly
Defeated and taken prisoner at Poitiers by The Black Prince
Released for hostages, returned to England when one escaped
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Bonne, Wife, img/hre/bonne_of_luxembourg.jpg

Charles V.name: Charles V
events: Treaty of Calais had granted southwestern France to Edward III
Recaptured all ceded territories and dispossesed King of Navarre
Support of Clement VII led to the great schism of the papacy

Charles VI.name: Charles VI
events: Attempted to install Avignon antipope Clement VII in Rome
Went mad, after which Burgundy and Orleans vied for power
After defeat at Agincourt, named Henry V of England his heir
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Isabeau, Wife, img/hre/isabeau_bavaria.jpg

Charles VII.name: Charles VII
events: Disinherited by father in favor of Henry V of England
Reclaimed Paris and northern France with help of Joan of Arc
Ended the civil war between houses of Valois and Orleans

Louis XI.name: Louis XI
events: Faced an alliance of Burgundy, Brittany, and England
Dismantled alliance, finally killing Duke of Burgundy in battle
Ended reign with Burgundy, Picardy, Boulonnais, and Artois
relationships: Italy, Charlotte of Savoy, Wife, img/italy/charlotte_savoy.jpg

Charles VIII.name: Charles VIII
events: Married Anne of Brittany to prevent encirclement by Habsburgs
Forfeited Artois and Franche-Comté acquired through Margaret
Pressed claim on Angevin Naples, triggering Italian Wars
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Margaret of Austria, Betrothed, img/hre/margaret_of_austria.jpg
Naples, Marie of Anjou, Grandmother, img/italy/marie_of_anjou.jpg

Louis XII.name: Louis XII
events: Duke of Orleans, second-cousin and brother-in-law to king
Conquered Milan but lost Naples to Ferdinand II of Aragon
Defeated in Milan & Artois by Swiss and Burgundy by Henry VIII

Francis I.name: Francis I
events: Cousin and son-in-law to Louis XII, first of Angoulême branch
Defeated Milan; with riches, copied an Italian renaissance court
Imprisoned by Emperor Charles V, gave up Italy for his release
relationships: Italy, Duke of Savoy, Son-in-law, img/italy/emmanuel_of_savoy.jpg

Henry II.name: Henry II
events: Developed a court system between local justices and high court
Supported German Protestants against Emperor Charles V
Systematically persecuted French Protestants
relationships: Florence, Catherine de' Medici, Wife, img/italy/catherine_de_medici.jpg

Francis II.name: Francis II
events: Used by the Guises, wife's uncle, to quell the Huguenot forces
Faced capture by Huguenot Bourbons to end Guise influence
Forced to sign Treaty of Edinburgh: end of Scottish influence
relationships: Scotland, Mary Queen of Scots, Wife, img/scotland/mary.jpg
Florence, Catherine de' Medici, Mother, img/italy/catherine_de_medici.jpg

Charles IX.name: Charles IX
events: Planned intervention on behalf of Protestants against Spain
Remained under influence of mother, Catherine de Medicis
On her advice, allowed a massacre of 3,000 Protestants in Paris
relationships: Florence, Catherine de' Medici, Mother, img/italy/catherine_de_medici.jpg
Holy Roman Empire, Maximilian II, Father-in-law, img/hre/maximillian_ii.jpg

Henry III.name: Henry III
events: Placed on Polish throne by mother, resigned when brother died
Holy League formed against Huguenot successor, Henry IV
Forced by League, which had rebelled, into alliance with Henry

Henry IV.name: Henry IV
events: First Bourbon, leader of Huguenot forces as King of Navarre
Huguenots massacred on the day of his appeasement marriage
Fought Holy League but converted to claim and unify the throne
relationships: Florence, Marie de Medici, Wife, img/italy/marie_de_medici.jpg

Louis XIII.name: Louis XIII
events: While wars of religion had ended, still faced Huguenot rebellions
Invading Italy, France entered Thirty Years War against Spain
Defeated Spain, establishing France as a global superpower
relationships: Spain, Anne of Austria, Wife, img/spain/anne_of_austria.jpg

Louis XIV.name: Louis XIV
events: Extended eastern borders at the expense of Austrian Habsburgs
Defeated hostile Spanish coalition to secure throne for grandson
Known as the Sun King, led a revival of culture and grandeur

Louis XV.name: Louis XV
events: Lost all colonial possessions in Americans and India to British
Gained nothing from Austria or Russia during partition of Poland
Through ineffective wars, set the stage for the French Revolution

Louis XVI.name: Louis XVI
events: Financed American revolution, leaving country deeply in debt
Forced to accept National Assembly and constitutional monarchy
Soliciting intervention, convicted of treason by French Republic
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Maria Josepha of Saxony, Mother, img/hre/maria_josepha.jpg
Holy Roman Empire, Marie Antoinette, Wife, img/hre/marie_antoinette.jpg

Napoleon I.name: Napoleon I
events: Rose from soldier to general to consul to emperor over 11 years
Defeated series of coalitions, collapsing the Holy Roman Empire
Lost army invading Russia, turning tide and was exiled to Elba

Louis XVIII.name: Louis XVIII
events: Exiled in revolution, wandered Europe promoting royalist cause
As Napoleon fell, promised to honor the republic's reforms
Restored by Talleyrand, coalition, and war-weary Parisians

Napoleon I.name: Napoleon I
events: Frustrated by Bourbon Restoration and Congress of Vienna
Escaped, gathered forces, and marched on Paris to applause
Defeated at Waterloo by coalition and banished to St. Helena

Louis XVIII.name: Louis XVIII
events: Fled during the Hundred Day's War, returning after Waterloo
Gave Parliament control over laws and budget with his approval
Resisted the ultraroyalists in favor of healing the country

Charles X.name: Charles X
events: Reimposed death penaly for sacrilege during first government
In second government, supported ultraroyalist clericalists
Deposed, naming grandson heir and Louis-Philippe general

Louis Philippe I.name: Louis Philippe I
events: Popular with republicans and Bonaparists, given a vacant throne
Seen as a citizen king, favored the bourgeoisie over aristocracy
Refusing any election reform, deposed in 1848 wave of socialism

Napoleon III.name: Napoleon III
events: Elected President of Second Republic after Revolution of 1848
Declared himself Emperor under the Second French Empire
Deposed after defeat in the Franco-Prussian War

Gorm.name: Gorm
events: Son of the semi-legendary Danish king Harthacnut
Completed the Danevirke, a wall separating the southern Saxons

Harald Bluetooth.name: Harald Bluetooth
events: First ruler of a united Denmark: Jutland and Zealand
Introduced Christianity to Denmark

William I.name: William I
events: As Duke of Normandy, led the invading Norman forces
Defeated King Harold Godwinson at the Battle of Hastings
Left England to William Rufus and Normandy to Robert Curthose

William II.name: William II
events: Faced a rebellion by barons who wanted a unified Norman rule
Undermined authority of Church, exiling the Archbishop
Killed Malcolm III, turning Scotland into an English vassal

Henry I.name: Henry I
events: Fought brother, Duke of Normandy, for English succession
Encouraged to invade Normandy, imprisoning brother for life
After son drowned, recalled daughter Matilda to be his heir
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Henry V, Son-in-law, img/hre/henry_v.jpg

Stephen.name: Stephen
events: Favorite nephew of Henry I, disregarded claim by aunt Matilda
Civil war, the Anarchy, began with the invasion of Matilda's army
Settled the war by signing a treaty naming Matilda's son his heir

Henry II.name: Henry II
events: Count of Anjou through father and Aquitaine through wife
Unpopular for murder of Archbishop and support of antipope
Restored order following Anarchy with new judicial system

Richard I.name: Richard I
events: Romanticized and made popular for exploits in Third Crusade
Vied to appoint King of Jerusalem, perhaps killing a candidate
Captured on return and ransomed in exchange for his kingdom

John.name: John
events: Lost Normandy and all French holdings to French Philip II
After a revolt of English barons, forced to seal the Magna Carta
First king since Norman Conquest who could speak English
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Isabella, Daughter, img/hre/isabella.jpg

Henry III.name: Henry III
events: Inherited a country ruled by rebellious barons, loyal to France
Financed papal wars in exchange for Sicilian crown for his son
Forced into Provisions of Oxford, establishing privy council

Edward I.name: Edward I
events: Held parliaments and made it into a feature of English politics
Killed Llywelyn ap Gruffudd, destroying autonomy of Wales
Arbitrated in favor of John Balliol, but invaded after he rebelled

Edward II.name: Edward II
events: Ordinances of 1311 restricted power of king's appointments
Defeated by Robert the Bruce at Battle of Bannockburn
Favoritism caused wife to depose him and crown their son

Edward III.name: Edward III
events: Installed puppet, Edward Balliol, after death of Robert the Bruce
Pressed claim to French throne, sparking Hundred Years' War
During war, acquired Aquitaine but lost it and only kept Brittany

Richard II.name: Richard II
events: Succeeded grandfather after father, the Black Prince, died young
Introduced unpopular tax to finance French war, leading to revolt
Deposed by duke of Lancaster, whose inheritance Richard stole
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Anne, Wife, img/hre/anne_plantagenet.jpg

Henry IV.name: Henry IV
events: Returned from exile after Richard II stole his possessions
Executed Archbishop of York and son of Duke of Norfolk
Imprisoned James I of Scotland for entire reign

Henry V.name: Henry V
events: Defeated France at Agincourt, allowing conquest of Normandy
Taking Rouen and allying with Burgundy, France surrendered
The Treaty of Troyes made him heir to the French throne
relationships: France, Catherine of Valois, Wife, img/france/catherine_valois.jpg

Henry VI.name: Henry VI
events: Ascended as a minor, with power held by cousin Duke of York
Captured by Yorkists, who demanded they name a York heir
Routed at Yorkshire, fled to Scotland, captured, and imprisoned
relationships: France, Margaret of Anjou, Wife, img/france/margaret_anjou.jpg

Edward IV.name: Edward IV
events: Defeated the Lancastrians with help of cousin, Earl of Warwick
Alienated Warwick and Yorkist nobles by marrying commoner
Warwick invaded, Edward fled, and Henry Lancaster released

Henry VI.name: Henry VI
events: Restored to the throne from the Tower of London
Edward IV returned and defeated Margaret's forces
Re-imprisoned and murdered shortly afterwards
relationships: France, Margaret of Anjou, Wife, img/france/margaret_anjou.jpg

Edward IV.name: Edward IV
events: Defeated the Lancaster forces, killing the heir at Tewkesbury
Made peace with France in return for a generous pension
Promiscuity led to brother Richard question the validity of sons

Edward V.name: Edward V
events: Along with brother Richard, two surviving sons of Edward IV
Crowned at age 12 without regency, at insistence of Woodvilles
Likely murdered in the Tower of London by uncle Richard

Richard III.name: Richard III
events: Usurped power from nephew, Edward V, who 'disappeared'
Woodvilles, family of slain nephew, rallied behind Henry Tudor
Killed at Battle of Bosworth Field, ending the War of the Roses

Henry VII.name: Henry VII
events: Went into exile after the defeat of the Lancastrian cause
Married Elizabeth of York, but still faced Yorkish conspiracies
Made peace with Spain and Scotland through careful marriages
relationships: Spain, Catherine of Aragon, Daughter-in-law, img/spain/catherine_of_aragon.jpg

Henry VIII.name: Henry VIII
events: Presided over the beginnings of the English Reformation
Unified England, Wales, and Ireland
Married to Catherine of Aragon, Anne Boleyn, and many others
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Charles V, Brother-in-law, img/hre/charles_v.jpg

Edward VI.name: Edward VI
events: Devoted Protestant, ruled through regency of Earl of Warwick
Excluded half-sisters Mary and Elizabeth from line of succession
Convinced by Warwick to name cousin Jane Grey, a Protestant

Jane Grey.name: Jane Grey
events: Maneuvered onto the throne by her uncle, Earl of Warwick
Overthrown by Mary Tudor with support of the populace
Imprisoned and pardoned, but executed after Wyatt's Rebellion

Mary I.name: Mary I
events: The first queen to rule England in her own right
Known as Bloody Mary for her persecutions of Protestants
Defeated Wyatt's Rebellion, but died unpopular and childless
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Charles V, Engaged, img/hre/charles_v.jpg
Spain, Catherine of Aragon, Mother, img/spain/catherine_of_aragon.jpg

Elizabeth I.name: Elizabeth I
events: Crafted political symbolism, establishing a cult of her virginity
Executed Mary, Queen of Scots, to end Catholic cause
Childless, named Protestant Scottish king James VI as her heir

James I.name: James I
events: Clashed with English Parliament over his idea of absolutism
Authorized English translation of bible, the King James Version
Faced an assassination by Guy Fawkes, the Gunpowder Plot
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Frederick V, Son-in-law, img/hre/frederick_v.jpg
Spain, Infanta Maria Anna, Attempted match, img/spain/maria_anna.jpg
Scotland, Mary Queen of Scots, Mother, img/scotland/mary.jpg

Charles I.name: Charles I
events: Quarreled with Parliament, provoking the English Civil War
After six years of war, captured, put on trial, and executed
Oliver Cromwell takes over the Puritan Commonwealth

Charles II.name: Charles II
events: Fighting for his father, escaped to France after losing to Cromwell
With no good successor to Cromwell, restored by Parliament
Secretly converted to Catholicism for French help against Dutch
relationships: Portugal, Catherine of Braganza, Wife, img/portugal/catherine.jpg
Dutch Republic, William of Orange, Nephew, img/england/william_iii_and_ii.jpg

James II.name: James II
events: Converted to Catholicism and repealed anti-Catholic laws
Ordered bishops to offer indulgences, leading to public protests
Protestant nobles invited William of Orange to come take throne
relationships: Italy, Mary of Modena, Wife, img/italy/mary_modena.jpg

William III.name: William III
events: Seen by Protestants as a hero, saving Europe from the French
Faced Irish rebellions, the Jacobites, supporting James II
Passed the Act of Settlement, excluding Catholics from throne
relationships: Dutch Republic, William II, Father, img/dutch/william_ii.jpg

Anne.name: Anne
events: Relied heavily on ministers, who led the war effort
Supported Tories, then Whigs, swayed by her current favorites
Succession passed over 57 candidates to Protestant Hanovers

George I.name: George I
events: Supported by Whigs over James Stuart, The Old Pretender
Unable to speak English, relied on Walpole, first Prime Minister
Embroiled in controversy over collapse of South Sea Company
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Ernest Augustus, Father, img/hre/ernest_augustus.jpg

George II.name: George II
events: Through John Carteret, joined the War of Austrian Succession
Accused of supporting his German holdings over England
Largely observed ministers leading Seven Years' War in France
relationships: Prussia, Frederick the Great, Nephew, img/hre/frederick_ii.jpg
Holy Roman Empire, Caroline of Ansbach, Wife, img/hre/caroline_ansbach.jpg

George III.name: George III
events: Attempted to finance Seven Years' War through colonial taxation
Lost American colonies to revolution, but united with Ireland
Fought with Revolutionary France to retain hold on aristocracy
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, Wife, img/hre/charlotte_mecklenburg.jpg

George IV.name: George IV
events: Served as regent during father's period of madness
Catholic Emancipation removed restrictions on Catholics
Retiring from politics, was known as an astute patron of the arts
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Caroline of Brunswick, Wife, img/hre/caroline_brunswick.jpg

William IV.name: William IV
events: Oversaw the abolition of slavery, child labor, and welfare
Childless, British crown went to Victoria; Hanoverian to brother
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Adelaide of Saxe-Meinigen, Wife, img/hre/adelaide.jpg

Victoria.name: Victoria
events: Indian Rebellion causes British East India Company to dissolve
Through Prince Albert, descended much of European royalty
Solidified holdings in Suez Canal, Cyprus, and across Africa
relationships: German Confederation, Prince Albert, Husband, img/hre/prince_albert.jpg
German Empire, Frederick William, Son-in-law, img/hre/frederick_william.jpg

Edward VII.name: Edward VII
events: Immensely popular, known as the  Uncle of Europe
Excluded from cabinet by mother who disapproved of affairs
Helped enact the Parliament Act, limiting the House of Lords
relationships: German Empire, Wilhelm II, Nephew, img/hre/wilhelm_ii.jpg

George V.name: George V
events: Granted home rule to Ireland
Renamed house from Saxe-Coburg and Gotha to Windsor
Formed a coalition government of Liberal and Conservative
relationships: German Empire, Wilhelm II, Cousin, img/hre/wilhelm_ii.jpg

Edward VIII.name: Edward VIII
events: Voluntarily abdicated in order to marry American divorcee
Implicated in plot to restore him to throne as a Nazi agent
Governer of The Bahamas, then lived in Paris after the war

George VI.name: George VI
events: Supported appeasement policy towards Germany until Churchill
Ceased to be emperor of India and Pakistan after independence
Oversaw British Empire turn into Commonwealth of Nations

Elizabeth II.name: Elizabeth II
events: Married her cousin, Philip Mountbatten of Greece and Denmark
Allowed television crews into domestic life, modernizing family
Plays a completely ceremonial role, staying out of politics

Malcolm III.name: Malcolm III
events: Lived in exile during reign of Macbeth, his father's killer
After Norman conquest, gave refuge to Edgar the Ætheling
Attempted conquest of Northumbria, dying in battle to William II

Donald Bane.name: Donald Bane
events: Beseiged Edinburgh Castle with support of Celtic Scots
Expelled by nephew Duncan II with support of English and Normans

Duncan II.name: Duncan II
events: Grew up as English hostage, as father's homage to William I
Deposed uncle Donald Bane, who then had him killed

Donald Bane.name: Donald Bane
events: Had nephew Duncan II killed after just a few months
Deposed by an English army led by Edgar the Ætheling
Replaced by other nephew, Edgar, son of Malcolm III

Edgar.name: Edgar
events: Placed on Scottish throne with aid of William II of England
First Scottish king to have Celtic and Anglo-Saxon ancestry
Ceded the Hebrides to Magnus III of Norway

Alexander I.name: Alexander I
events: Allowed younger brother, David, to rule southern Scotland
Likely acknolwedged Henry I of England has his overlord
Attempted to preserve the independence of the Scottish Church

David I.name: David I
events: Supported his niece, Empress Matilda, over Stephen of Blois
Granted Northumbria and Cumbria for fighting in The Anarchy
Annexed the Mormaer of Moray to the Scottish crown

Malcolm IV.name: Malcolm IV
events: Ascended throne at age of 11, grandson of David I
Forced to give Northumbria and Cumbria back to Henry II
Succeeded by his brother, William the Lion

William I.name: William I
events: Revolted to win back Northumbria but captured by Henry II
As part of release, confirmed the supremacy of English Church
Bought release of feudal subjection from Richard I

Alexander II.name: Alexander II
events: Supported the English barons' revolt, hoping to reclaim land
Established Anglo-Scottish border through the Treaty of York

Alexander III.name: Alexander III
events: Gained Isle of Man and Hebrides from Norwegian Haakon IV

Margaret.name: Margaret
events: Only surviving descendant of grandfather, Alexander III
Sailed from Norway to take crown, but died en route
Her death led to thirteen claims to the throne, the Great Cause

John.name: John
events: Selected among competitors during Great Cause
Deposed by Scottish nobility who'd signed a treaty with France
Imprisoned in Tower of London and exiled to Papal States

Robert I.name: Robert I
events: Claimed throne while under rule of Edward I of England
Defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn
Finally made peace with England after deposition of Edward II
relationships: Ireland, Elizabeth de Burgh, Wife, img/ireland/elizabeth_de_burgh.jpg

David II.name: David II
events: Sent to France for safety after losing the Battle of Halidon Hill
Captured by the English and held for 11 years
relationships: England, Joan of the Tower, Wife, img/england/joan_of_the_tower.jpg

Robert II.name: Robert II
events: Defeated the return of Edward Balliol and the English
Included Scotland in the Anglo-French truce of 1384

Robert III.name: Robert III
events: Albany Stewart, his brother, had effective control over kingdom
Son David captured and killed by Albany
Other son, James, fled to France but was captured by Henry IV

James I.name: James I
events: While a captive of Henry IV, raised in the English court
Arrested the Lord of the Isles and the Douglas clan leaders
Was murdered during a failed coup by uncle, Walter Stewart

James II.name: James II
events: Murdered Earl of Douglas for consipiring with Lord of the Isles
Killed by friendly fire during the seige of an English castle
relationships: Flanders, Mary of Guelders, Wife, img/france/mary_guelders.jpg

James III.name: James III
events: Received Orkney and Shetland Islands as dowry from Norway
Imprisoned by Edward IV in Edinburgh Castle
Killed during a rebellion at the Battle of Sauchieburn

James IV.name: James IV
events: Defeated his father, James III, at the Battle of Sauchieburn
Signed the Treaty of Perpetual Peace with Henry VII
Took away the Lord of the Isles title from the MacDonalds
wars: War of the League of Cambrai

James V.name: James V
events: Imprisoned by his stepfather Archibald Douglas for 3 years
Persecuted Protestants during the Scottish Reformation
His death left the infant Mary, Queen of Scots as the heir
relationships: France, Mary of Guise, Wife, img/france/mary_guise.jpg

Mary, Queen of Scots.name: Mary, Queen of Scots
events: Arriving from France, imprisoned by Protestants and deposed
Believed by English Catholics to be the legitimate heir to Mary I
After 18 years in English custody, beheaded by Elizabeth I

James VI.name: James VI
events: Taken from Mary, Queen of Scots and raised as a Protestant
Ingratiated himself to the childless Elizabeth I to be named her heir
Colonized the Hebrides in an attempt to de-gaelicise it
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Frederick V, Son-in-law, img/hre/frederick_v.jpg
Spain, Infanta Maria Anna, Attempted match, img/spain/maria_anna.jpg

Vladimir the Great.name: Vladimir the Great
events: Expanded Kievan realm to include Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine
Converted to Christianity and Christianized the pagan Rus'
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Otto I, Grandfather-in-law, img/hre/otto_i.jpeg

Sviatopolk I.name: Sviatopolk I
events: Known as 'The Accursed', murdered his 3 brothers to seize power
Defeated in battle by remaining brother, Yaroslav

Yaroslav the Wise.name: Yaroslav the Wise
events: Enacted code of law known as Russkaya Pravda, the Rus Truth
Captured part of Crimea from the Byzantine Empire
Captured Estonia with the help of Scandinavian allies
relationships: England, Edgar the Ætheling, Grandson, img/england/edgar_aethling.jpg

Iziaslav I.name: Iziaslav I
events: Founded the first Kievan Eastern Orthodox monastery
Fled during popular uprising, then returned with help from Polish
Crowned first King of Rus' by the Pope

Sviatoslav II.name: Sviatoslav II
events: Joined brothers Iziaslav and Vsevolod in a triumvirate of Kiev
With support of Vsevolod, dethroned and replaced Iziaslav

Vsevolod I.name: Vsevolod I
events: United the core principalities of Kiev, Chernigov, and Pereyaslav
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Henry IV, Son-in-law, img/hre/henry_iv.jpg

Sviatopolk II.name: Sviatopolk II
events: Engaged in campaigns against the Kypchaks but defeated in 1093
Attemped compact with Chernigov by inviting Cuman raiders
Embellished the golden-roofed St. Michael's Abbey in Kiev

Vladimir II.name: Vladimir II
events: Engaged in constant warfare with the Turkic Cumans
Held series of congresses to unite Rus' princes against Great Steppe

Mstislav I.name: Mstislav I
events: Fought the Cumans, Estonians, and Lithuanians for entire reign
After death, united Rus broke apart for four hundred years

Ivan IV.name: Ivan IV
events: Established the Tsardom of Russia with Moscow at the center
Conquered Khanates of Kazan, Astrakhan, and Sibir
Transformed Russia from medieval state to complex empire

Feodor I.name: Feodor I
events: Last Rurikid Tsar of Russia
Country administered by brother-in-law, Boris Godunov
Dying childless, plunged Russia into the Time of Troubles

Boris Godunov.name: Boris Godunov
events: Rose through the ranks from soldier to favorite to minister
Separated Russian Orthodox Church from Constantinople

Feodor II.name: Feodor II
events: Proclaimed Tsar after the death of father
Envoys of False Dmitriy publicly read his fate in Red Square
Boyars, disloyal to new Tsar, arrested, strangled, and poisoned him

False Dmitry.name: False Dmitry
events: One of three pretenders claiming to be son of Ivan the Terrible
Formed army with support of Poland, marching against Godunov
Promised Russian Church back to Rome, inciting death by mob

Vasili IV.name: Vasili IV
events: Plotted against False Dmitry, taking throne after his death
Deposed and forced into a monastery, dying a prisoner

Michael I.name: Michael I
events: Elected Tsar, taking Russia back from the Kingdom of Poland
Accession marked the end of the Time of Troubles
Conquered Siberia with help of cossacks and Stroganov family

Alexis I.name: Alexis I
events: Excommunicated Patriarch Nikon, who attempted a Greek reform
Faced riots over salt, copper, and Cossacks led by Stenka Razin
Ended his reign with 8,000,000 square kilometers under his rule

Feodor III.name: Feodor III
events: Founded the academy of sciences in Zaikonospassky Monastery
Introduced reforms such as meritocracy, Greek, and beard shaving
Died without issue, sparking the Moscow Uprising of 1682

Peter I.name: Peter I
events: Westenized Russia, traveling Europe and founding St. Petersburg
Captured ports at Azov and Baltic Sea from Swedes and Tatars
Transformed Russia into modern, scientific Enlightened empire

Catherine I.name: Catherine I
events: Succeeded husband, since heir Alexei was convicted of treason
Continued liberalization, opening door to female monarchs

Peter II.name: Peter II
events: Son of Peter I through his first wife, Charlotte Christine
Disinclined to rule, spent time feasting and died quite young
Last male heir of the Romanov line
relationships: Holy Roman Empire, Louis Rudolph, Grandfather, img/hre/louis_rudolph.jpg

Anna.name: Anna
events: Daughter of half-brother of Peter I's invalid half-brother, Ivan V
Continued reforms in architecture, science, and the arts
Named grand-nephew Ivan VI heir to exclude lineage of Peter I

Ivan VI.name: Ivan VI
events: Declared Emperor at the age of two months
Imprisoned after a year by cousin Elizabeth, who launched a coup
After twenty years in captivity, killed by guards during failed rescue

Elizabeth.name: Elizabeth
events: Invested heavily in architecture, such as the Winter Palace
Received all of Southern Finland from Sweden in Treaty of Åbo
Died unexpectedly before defeating Prussia in Seven Years' War

Peter III.name: Peter III
events: Nephew to Elizabeth, first of Holstein-Gottorp-Romanov house
A progressive, granted religion freedom and abolished secret police
Overthrown by wife Princess Sophie, who became Catherine II

Catherine II.name: Catherine II
events: Oversaw the breakup of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth
Gained Crimea and Poland; colonized Novorossia and Alaska
An enlightened absolutist, brought about an artistic renaissance
relationships: Sweden, Gustave IV Adolf, Cousin, img/sweden/gustav_iv_adolf.jpg

Paul I.name: Paul I
events: Added eastern Georgia to the empire
Allied with Britain and Austria against Napeolonic France
Creating policies unfriendly to nobles, was assassinated by military
relationships: Prussia, Frederick II Eugene, Father-in-law, img/germany/frederick_eugene.jpg

Alexander I.name: Alexander I
events: King of Poland and Grand Duke of Finland during unity periods
Napoleon's army collapsed during invasion, losing 500,000 men
Joined Holy Alliance with Austria and Prussia to combat revolutions

Nicholas I.name: Nicholas I
events: Seized the last territories in the Caucasus held by Persia
Lost Crimean War and influence over Romania, Serbia, & Black Sea
On eve of death, Russian territory was at its zenith: 8MM sq. miles
relationships: Prussia, Frederick William III, Father-in-law, img/germany/frederick_william_iii.jpg

Alexander II.name: Alexander II
events: Emancipated Russian serfs, for which he is known as The Liberator
Sold Alaska to the United States to prevent it from becoming British
Pursued further expansion into Siberia, Caucasus, and Turkestain
relationships: German Confederation, Louis II, Father-in-law, img/germany/louis_ii.jpg

Alexander III.name: Alexander III
events: A counter-reformer, reversed many of his father's policies
Formed Triple Entente alliance with France and Great Britain

Nicholas II.name: Nicholas II
events: Lost influence over Manchuria and Korea to the Japanese
Lost 3.3 million Russians during World War I, causing revolution
Abdicated, imprisoned, and handed over to Bolsheviks for execution

Otto I.name: Otto I
events: Ended the Hungarian invasions of Western Europe
Conquered Northern Italy
Invaded papal states and installed Leo VIII as pope
relationships: England, Edward the Elder, Father-in-law, img/england/edward_the_elder.jpg

Otto II.name: Otto II
events: Subjugated and christianized the Danes
Attempted and failed to take Italy from the Muslims

Otto III.name: Otto III
events: Lost territories east of the Elbe to Slavs
Died without heir, causing Italy to break away

Henry II.name: Henry II
events: Crowned King of Germany following death of Otto III
Added Bohemia to the empire
Support for Rome led to the East-West Schism of the Church

Conrad II.name: Conrad II
events: Claimed the vacant Dukedom of Bavaria
Incorporated the heirless Kingdom of Burgundy

Henry III.name: Henry III
events: Given Bavaria, Swabia, and Burgundy from father Conrad II
Trial of Italian bishop precipitated Investiture Controversy
Split Lorraine into Upper and Lower Lorraine
relationships: Denmark, Cnut the Great, Father-in-law, img/denmark/cnut_the_great.jpg

Henry IV.name: Henry IV
events: Attempted to appoint bishops instead of the papacy
Excommunicated 5 times during Investiture Controversy
Defeated by son Henry with support of papacy

Henry V.name: Henry V
events: Captured Pope Paschal II
Settled Investiture Controversy in Concordat of Worms

Lothair II.name: Lothair II
events: Appointed Duke of Saxony for supporting Henry V against father
First elected Emperor without hereditary claim

Frederick I.name: Frederick I
events: Created feudal court via Landfrieden of 1152
Defeated at Alessandria by pro-papal Lombard League
Reconciled with Pope Alexander II at Peace of Venice

Henry VI.name: Henry VI
events: Captured and ransomed Richard the Lionheart of England
Captured and added Sicily to the Empire
Attempted and failed to make imperial crown hereditary

Otto IV.name: Otto IV
events: Son of anti-king Henry the Lion
Excommunicated by Pope Innocent III
Frederick II elected concurrently by dissatisfied princes and Pope

Frederick II.name: Frederick II
events: Appointed king of Sicily and Jerusalem through marriage
Outlawed the practice of Trial by Ordeal
After death, Empire entered a period of long decline

Henry VII.name: Henry VII
events: Elected over French Charles of Valois as King of the Romans
Swung support amongst Italians to pro-Empire Ghibelline faction
Coronation ended the Great Interregnum of the empire

Louis IV.name: Louis IV
events: Elected over Habsburg cousin with support of Luxembourgs
Gave Teutonic Knights permission to invade Lithuania and Russia
Lost support of German princes to Charles IV of Luxembourg

Charles IV.name: Charles IV
events: Crowned King of the Romans during the reign of Louis IV
Established Imperial succession in Golden Bull of 1356

Sigismund.name: Sigismund
events: Founded the Order of the Dragon to fight the Turks
Ended Papal Schism through the Council of Constance
Had Jan Hus executed after promising safe passage

Frederick III.name: Frederick III
events: Last Emperor to be crowned in Rome
Consolidated ancestral Habsburg land of Austria and Hungary

Maximilian I.name: Maximilian I
events: Proclaimed Emperor-elect at Trent
Lost Swiss territories to Swiss Confederacy
Established Habsburg dynasty in Spain via son's marriage to queen of Castile
relationships: Burgundy, Charles the Bold, Father-in-law, img/france/charles_the_bold.jpg

Charles V.name: Charles V
events: Financed conquistadores for Incan and Aztec expeditions
Organized Diet of Worms to halt the Protestant Reformation
Divided empire between Spanish and Austrian Habsburgs

Ferdinand I.name: Ferdinand I
events: Consolidated grasp over Hungary
Led Counter-Reformation, the Catholic response to Protestantism
relationships: Poland, Sigismund II Augustus, Son-in-law, img/poland/sigismund_ii_augustus.jpg

Maximilian II.name: Maximilian II
events: Established temporary peace with Protestants during the Confessionalization
Failed to evict Ottoman Turks from Hungary

Rudolf II.name: Rudolf II
events: Ineffectual ruler whose mistakes led to the Thirty Years' War
Influential patron of Northern Mannerist art
Intellectual devotee who helped seed the scientific revolution

Matthias.name: Matthias
events: Gave freedom of religion to the Dutch in Union of Utrecht
Imprisoned and stripped brother Rudolf II of all titles and land
Imprisoned Protestant leader Klesl during Bohemian Protestant revolt

Ferdinand II.name: Ferdinand II
events: A zealous Catholic, led the Thirty Years' War against Protestants
Put down Bohemian revolt led by Protestant Emperor Frederick V
Ended civil war component by signing Peace of Prague in 1635
relationships: Florence, Eleanor de' Medici, Mother-in-law, img/italy/eleanor_de_medici.jpg

Ferdinand III.name: Ferdinand III
events: Appointed head of the Imperial army during Thirty Years' War
Made peace with Protestant league in 1648 with Peace of Westphalia
relationships: Spain, Maria Anna, Wife & Cousin, img/spain/maria_anna.jpg
Spain, Philip IV, Brother-in-law & Son-in-law, img/spain/philip_iv.jpg

Leopold I.name: Leopold I
events: Received all of Kingdom of Hungary from Turks
Challenged the will of Spanish Charles II leaving Spain to France
relationships: Spain, Margaret Theresa, Wife & Cousin, img/spain/margaret_theresa.jpg

Joseph I.name: Joseph I
events: Re-established Austrian hegemony over Italy

Charles VI.name: Charles VI
events: Issued Pragmatic Sanction of 1713 establishing daughter Maria Theresa heiress
Ceded overseas trading company in exchange for foreign recognition
Upon death, recognition was reneged, leading to War of the Austrian Succession

Charles VII.name: Charles VII
events: Elected Holy Roman Emperor over Maria Theresa through Salic Law
Overrun by Austrian Habsburg-Lorraine troops and fled to Frankfurt
Posthumously recognized by Habsburgs as Holy Roman Emperor

Francis I.name: Francis I
events: Won the War of Austrian Succession with Habsburg wife Maria Theresa
Pursued business while wife managed the affairs of the Empire

Joseph II.name: Joseph II
events: Valuing the Enlightenment, unsuccessfully attempted reforms
Passed 1783 Edict of Tolerance giving some freedom of religion
Opposed by Hungarian nobles and died ruined and abandoned

Leopold II.name: Leopold II
events: Publicly vowed to intervene in French Revolution in 1791
Contested for power over Hungary with King of Prussia
Contested for power over Poland with Catherine the Great

Francis II.name: Francis II
events: Defeated by Napoleon at the Battle of Austerlitz
Founded the Austrian Empire, becoming its first Emperor
Served as first president of German Confederation in 1815

Francis I.name: Francis I
events: Dissolved the Holy Roman Empire after defeat at Austerlitz
Founded the Austrian Empire from the Habsburg Monarchy
Served as first president of German Confederation from 1815

Ferdinand I.name: Ferdinand I
events: Suffered from seizures, hydrocephaly, and speech impediment
Considered unfit, not allowed to rule independently
Abdicated during Revolutions of 1848 in favor of nephew
relationships: Sardinia, Victor Emmanuel I, Father-in-law, img/italy/victor_emmanuel_sardinia.jpg

Franz Joseph I.name: Franz Joseph I
events: Lost claim to Tuscany and Northern Italy
Lost the leadership of pan-Germany (German Question) to Prussia
Annexed Bosnia and Herzegovina, precipitating World War I

Charles I.name: Charles I
events: Abdicated immediately after the armistice of World War I
Banished by the Austrian Parliament passing the Habsburg Law
Attempted to reclaim Hungary, which became a republic

Frederick I.name: Frederick I
events: Elevated Prussia to a kingdom through the Crown Treaty of 1700
In exchange, sent 8,000 men into War of Spanish Succession
Styled himself King in Prussia in deference to Poland
relationships: Dutch Republic, Frederick Henry, Grandfather, img/dutch/frederick_henry.jpg

Frederick William I.name: Frederick William I
events: Invited Protestant refugees to settled depopulated East Prussia
Invented the Canton System for better military conscription
Austere, left Prussia richer than any of the other German states

Frederick II.name: Frederick II
events: Declared himself King of Prussia
Gained Polish and Silesian territories from Austria
An 'enlightened absolutist', used power for the good of the people

Frederick William II.name: Frederick William II
events: Left Prussia near bankrupt due to his opulent lfiestyle
Acquired more Prussian land with third partition of Poland

Frederick William III.name: Frederick William III
events: His army defeated by Napoleon, he fled to the court of Russia
During the Congress of Vienna, secured territorial increases
Attempted to centralize all Protestant churches under royal control

Frederick William IV.name: Frederick William IV
events: A Romantic and conservative, opposed liberalism and socialism
Falsely promised a constitution during the Revolutions of 1848
Vied for pan-German leadership against the Austrian Empire

William I.name: William I
events: Settled German Question, taking leadership of pan-Germany
Founded the North German Confederation, then German Empire
Chancelor Otto von Bismarck created network of alliances

Frederick III.name: Frederick III
events: Attempted to reform government and remove office of Chancellor
Inherited throne with terminal cancer, dying after only 9 months
Throne went to son Wilhelm II, who had no liberal tendencies

Wilhelm II.name: Wilhelm II
events: Immediately dismissed chancelor Otto von Bismarck
Guaranteed support to Austria in 1914, leading to World War I
After defeat, lost the support of the army and the people
